review: This thing is a of very limited value, and I'm not sure that it's quite ready for prime time.  Yes, it works- more or less, and no- I don't see much utility from it.  This analogy may not mean much to non-nerds, but this to me is a bit like an Arduino or Raspberry Pi- you can get it to do some stuff if you are really determined, but it's not likely to be worth it.  No.  That's not fair to Arduino or Raspberry Pi- I've done far more interesting things with those.  The Chromecast is a bust.  The video quality is underwhelming, and the UI and connectivity are equally yawn-worthy.
author: Stucco

review: MY GOAL: Carry my content with me when I travel and watch it on the hotel TV A) Using minimal hardware and B) From the bedTRY #1: Miracast Dongle Receiving Content from Nexus 7 (FAIL)TRY #2: Google ChromeCast (Now that they've un-screwed the API) Receiving Content from Nexus 7 via AllCastAnyone who counters my low review with "It does what it says it does" is spot on; no argument here.That said: it doesn't do much.  The number of devices in my media cluster that can stream Netflix and everything else is huge.  The niche for this device is TV's dumb enough that they can't receive media but new enough they have got a spare HDMI port.  This really is just a transparent effort to shift commodity media purchase from {anyone else} to Google Play.  Mission accomplished.  And a really sweet price!What you can't do with the thing is talk to it without being on a consistent network.  Hotel and other remote networks are notoriously spotty and troublesome to work with.  And the dude who built AllCast -- who appears to otherwise be a freakin' genius and totally pulling for my goal -- has really gone out of his way to make the trial experience so unpleasant that buying the full version is just out of the question.  I could stream a second or two of video before it stopped to open a browser window.So anyway - it does not meet my needs.  Though my experience showed it to be a functional approach to streaming personal media under controlled conditions where MiraCast simply was not ever.MISSION: FAIL.
author: I_Will

review: Only supported web sites (such as YouTube, Google Play, or others they list) can "cast" directly to the device, allowing you to use your phone or laptop for other things while still watching the video in full-screen mode.  These types of sites seem to work well with this device.However, if your laptop does not have an HDMI connector and your TV does, and you want to watch something on your TV (via Chrome on your laptop), it is a different situation.  Your computer has to receive the stream and then forward it to the Chromecast device... and this process is more sensitive to WiFi signal levels in your home, which turned out to be a problem for me.  Even after installing the short HDMI extender, which improves WiFi reception a bit, our Wifi signal seems too weak to support "casting" from laptop screen to TV without having brief freezes in the video and skips in the audio, or audio slightly out of sync with the video.So, this device is just as good as a Roku if you are watching one of their supported channels or web sites, but demands more of your computer and Wifi network if you seek to "cast" a stream from Chrome on your laptop to the TV.  Both laptop and Chromecast seem to need to be in "good" WiFi reception zones, which is tough (and not very convenient) for us to do in our house.
